title: Cancer Progress: Much More Than You Wanted To Know
summary:
Key ideas:
- Official statistics suggest progress in the War on Cancer but skeptics offer a different view.
- Incidence rates for cancer have worsened since 1975 but age-adjusted death rates have improved since 1990.
- Improved social policies like discouraging smoking have been the primary reason for decreasing death rates.
- Five-year-survival rates have increased since 1970 but the improvement is confounded by improved screening.
- Adjusting for everything we know and are able to monitor, cancer survival rates seem to have increased.

Key learnings:
- Age-adjusted data shows that cancer death rates have been decreasing since 1990.
- Five-year-survival rates have been gradually improving since at least 1970, but improved screening confounds the improvement to some extent.
- Improved social policies like discouraging smoking have played a major role in decreasing death rates due to cancer.
- Researchers have investigated stage-specific survival rates to measure the effect of improved cancer treatment, and some gains in survival rates still remain even when adjusted for size.

Key questions:
- Which narrative is more accurate, official statistics or the view of skeptics?
- How much of the improvement in five-year survival rates can be attributed to improved screening?
- How effective have social policies like discouraging smoking been in decreasing death rates?
- How much of the gain in survival rates from improved cancer treatment is confounded by improved screening?
- Will future research reveal new confounders that take away the gains made in cancer treatment and diagnosis?
